title.narrative: 4. Ensuring the protection of prisoners sentenced to death’s rights

description.narrative: Assessment of achieved results: By publicising estimates of annual executions carried out in China, Dui Hua has provided transparency to the practice of capital punishment in China. Based on its internal death penalty log, Dui Hua has calculated that the average length of waiting time from the death sentence to execution is two months. This period, which is longer than originally expected, provides those seeking to intervene in death penalty cases a window to carry out intervention and advocacy.

comment.narrative: Dui Hua estimated that 2,400 executions were carried out in China in 2013, a sharp drop from the estimated 12,000 executions carried out in 2002. In 2013, state media publicised fewer executions and China confirmed in its Universal Periodic Review report that it would continue to reduce the number of executions, although not abolish the use of death penalty.

title.narrative: 1. Ensuring the protection of political and religious detainees and prisoners’ rights

description.narrative: Assessment of achieved results: Dui Hua conducts research by using open Chinese sources and PPDB is the world’s most comprehensive database of Chinese prisoners of conscience. Access to the PPDB is of significant value for Denmark to track personal cases, which are i.e. raised by Danish politicians. During Dui Hua’s exchanges with Chinese interlocutors, advocacy on behalf of prisoners of conscience have been carried out. Dui Hua is also the only organisation to successfully hand over prisoner lists to the Chinese government (973 names in 2014-2017) and receive written responses in return (193 names in 2014-2017) since 2012. Dui Hua also provides the lists handed by the EU to the China during the annual EU-China Human Rights dialogues. Additionally, 152 prisoner cases have been granted acts of clemency or better treatment on the prisoners list between 2014-2017, and 2,155 media mentions of Dui Hua’s research and publication has been registered, contributing to greater awareness.

comment.narrative: By the end of 2013, Dui Hua’s Political Prisoners Database (PPDB) hosted more than 28,000 entries, including approximately 5,000 active cases whose detention status were custodial, non-custodial or unclear. Religious cases, predominantly Falun Gong but also Protestant and Muslim cases, accounted for approximately half of the cases.

title.narrative: 3. Ensuring the protection of women in prison’s rights

description.narrative: Assessment of achieved results: Dui Hua has contributed to promote the Bangkok Rules through its publications and exchange programmes to key Chinese officials and the general Chinese public. After years of absence to address the problems of the lack of legal protection for domestic violence victims, China’s first Anti-Domestic Violence Law came into effect on 1 March 2016. However, the population of women in custody in China continues to rise; the Asian Pacific Conference on Correctional Administrators found that by the middle of 2015, China had more than 107,000 women in prison, which was an increase of 3,2 percent from the previous year, making it even more relevant to promote and protect the rights of female prisoners.

comment.narrative: The UN General Assembly adopted the Bangkok Rules in December 2010. Despite the worldwide growth of the number of women in prison, especially China, few policymakers and correctional officers are aware of the Bangkok Rules.

title.narrative: 2. Ensuring the protection of juvenile offenders’ rights

description.narrative: Assessment of achieved results: Dui Hua has contributed to the reform of the juvenile justice system in China through its exchange programmes by generating recommendations from American leading experts and increasing the awareness of best practices in the juvenile justice system among Chinese stakeholders. Non-custodial measures are crucial in minimising the chance of recidivism among juveniles, in ensuring their healthy development and facilitating their positive interaction with the community. According to China’s official compendium on juvenile justice and information gathered from Dui Hua interlocutors, courts sentenced 48 percent of juveniles to non-custodial measures and other punishment-exemption measures in 2015, which is an increase 41,7 percent in 2012 and 36 percent in 2010.

comment.narrative: China’s amended Criminal Procedure Law (CPL), which came into effect on 1 January 2013, includes for the first time a section on juvenile cases meant to reinforce the principle of “education first, punishment second”. Following Dui Hua’s third juvenile justice exchange with the Supreme People’s Court (SPC) Juvenile Court Guiding Group in 2012, Dui Hua’s staff met with the SPC judges in November 2013 to discuss the progress of reforms and future partnership.
